audio_caption: The audio clip opens with a single male speaker introducing the setting as "Wednesday," referring to a time "shade after two" and mentioning sorting buttons, identifying himself and another as "chain man." The speaker's tone is conversational and seemingly documentary. Ambient noise of wind is present throughout the clip. The speaker points out an object, referring to it as a "shovel," and then says to "stand by" to investigate activity "at the Cavalier, at the Ocean Front." The speaker lists some numbers: "12 39," "637," "15 39," mentioning that the target is "deep," then tells the listener to "stand by" while he examines an unknown object. He reports, "'1138' out," speculating about a bottle cap and concluding, "No, I don't think it's a bottle cap" as he sees it. The speaker states "I know it can't be no quarter or '1238'," and asks to be given a moment to dust off the object. The speaker says, "Don't think. Stand by a minute, let me get it dusted off here a little bit"

The audio clip starts with a male speaker examining an object, describing it as having "some kind of tag" with a hole, and mentions that there's something on it he can't make out. He directs someone, possibly a dog, to come over. Shortly after, the clip features rustling sounds. A second male speaker chimes in, unsure if it's "some kind of small piece thing" or some kind of latch for suspenders. There is then more rustling and the clip concludes with a rustling sound.

The clip begins with the sound of speech accompanied by intermittent shoveling. A male speaker remarks "Fine it". The shovel sounds continue as the same speaker exclaims "There it is". Another male speaker acknowledges, with agreement. The first speaker describes the item, observing it looks like a "skeleton key type thing". The second speaker responds, stating "I don't think it's too old" and compares it to similar items found in another location, later clarifying they used to "look like that" before plastic keys. The first speaker then says "I don't really" before indicating the roundness of an area. A change in tone precedes him saying "go here it is". He speaks to a "gizmo" on something. The second speaker states that he doesn't know what it goes to, but thinks it is a latch for a canvas and then specifies how one would use the thing. As the clip ends, the first speaker asks, "Bring in the shovel?".

A male speaker is heard bringing a shovel and preparing to dig. He finds himself surrounded by ice, and humorously refers to it as an iceberg, before suggesting he may have found a 2-pill nitro. He remarks on the ice and mentions a desire to move to California to find real gold. He states that what he has found might have been gold in its day. Afterward, he has located a wheat penny, but the other side is green, implying corrosion. The speaker concludes he will take some time to determine the coin’s year, hoping to find it.

The clip starts with a male speaker announcing "Okay, stand by," and commenting on the sunset visible behind trees. The speaker mentions finding something possibly cool, but doubts it's a belt buckle and suspects it's more likely something "crappy looking." There's a request to "stand by," before the recording ends.

The audio clip features speech from two male speakers. The first one asks “How you making out, Jay man?” The second man replies he is not making as much going south, and describes that a lot of the material he finds is minuscule. He then discusses finding small pieces of aluminum and copper, referring to digging up “two or three of them today.”  They continue to discuss the objects they are finding, including a possible .22 shell or a piece of pipe. The second speaker notes the challenges of finding small objects, saying one can “play around with this stuff all day.”  Throughout the speech, the prevalent ambient sound is the rhythmic crashing and sloshing of waves, indicating that the conversation is happening near an ocean or large body of water.

The clip begins with one male speaker expressing regret about not bringing a pinpointer, mentioning he didn't do it for a specific reason. He says, "It's sitting right in here, it's gotten brushed over." Another male voice adds "probably a piece of copper like you said" and explains that a button would be sticking out. The first speaker then announces that he is headed that way, and then is cut off by a short burst of static and an abrupt cut.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker, sounding slightly subdued, acknowledging a "round-up" that yielded few results. He describes finding "some ammo and some stuff," stating it's "enough to keep you busy but nothing to write home about." The audio primarily consists of speech with no audible music or background noise present.

The clip features a single male speaker describing several items he has found. He begins by questioning the origin of a brass tag, then identifies a possible "1924 Wheatie". He then discusses a ring with "ice", clarifying it's probably "cheap plated ring". The speaker seems generally conversational and casual. The audio ends with him mentioning a "knife dig tomorrow", transitioning to background frying sounds.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker announcing he is going to hunt for some old silver at an old house site that he hasn't been to since 2009. He concludes by wishing good luck to everyone. This speech is followed by the sound of static.
